body: Also noteworthy: benchmark results indicate that Spring Boot 2.2 is not significantly faster for this "stripped down" version of the app, but only if launched from the main class. The `JarLauncher` (and hence probably the `PropertiesLauncher` that is used in the docker container for zipkin-server) is *much* faster in Spring Boot 2.2. If we are going to continue to use that, it would be worthwhile to upgrade Spring Boot Maven plugin, even if the underlying library is held back to 2.1 for now. (BTW I tested with 2.2 as a library as well - had to explicitly pin the version for actuator jars, but it worked.)

since we don't support custom servers we can upgrade anything at any time. indeed worthwhile to check into the property loading.

PS The amount of time savings depends greatly on which configurations are used. Ad-hoc, the more the more savings, but I don't have a matrix. I will make a comment to such effect.

If only using the stock zipkin in-memory, you won't see anything much unless you set `--zipkin.internal.actuator.enabled=false`. Here's a best of 10 with it disabled:

Best of 10 this commit just `java -jar zipkin.jar`
```
1.854 seconds (JVM running for 2.578)
```

Best of 10 this commit `java -jar zipkin.jar --zipkin.internal.actuator.enabled=false`
```
1.681 seconds (JVM running for 2.434)
```

best in several for the elasticsearch use case mentioned in the description is about 120ms savings even with actuator left on.

It is still on plate to look at docker setup to see how much impact, but as there are still a lot of things from the startup bench talk still not implemented, will sync this for a bit. We can revisit things decoupled as we go along.
PPS the build from the skipActuator profile runs the same speed as skipping via the internal runtim parameter (Eventhough skipping compilation and inclusion reduces the size of the distribution)

thanks, sounds promising.

as it is going on a 15hr day so far, I'm gonna look more tomorrow. this sort of work is very time consuming.

@adriancole ready for another review, sorry for the delay. Let me know if anything is not clear or uncertain. Basically everything except core depends on sfl4j-api now, and in zipkin-server log4j-starter is still used. The goal of reducing server size is no longer relevant in this case. But it should be easier to bridge everything to a new logging impl, though it's not a simple matter of swapping out dependencies.

I tried this after adding the repo. I restarted it many times and couldn't find any difference between before and after. I triple checked the console output etc, including looking inside the jar.

Note that when you have network on (wifi enabled) something inside the app is more volatile in startup times. It could possibly be unrelated to your experience. I noticed yesterday that starting could take 7+ seconds on a bad wifi and on my list to trace the bootstrap to see if any dependencies are doing nasty things like making outgoing connections.
going to merge this as there's much left to do and I think these lines of code now rank as some of the most analyzed in the repo :P

closing this out, though thanks for the hint.

Our most analyzed start times come from docker, and there's no notable difference when launching from the main class in our setup of 2.1 vs 2.2. We've already pared down so much that this isn't terribly surprising.

once boot 2.2 is out, we'll surely upgrade.
In docker, this starts up in 3.5s on the current base image. This is .5s faster than not slim same base commit.
ok slim now no longer uses log4j2 due to work by @jorgheymans .. just need to get it to use slf4j-simple :P
-Dorg.slf4j.simpleLogger.log.zipkin2=debug totally works
We've done a lot of work since this started. Now, slim starts in less than 2s

Just checking, you were starting the app from the exploded archive? (I'm guessing not, otherwise your results are too different than mine.) Maybe I'm reading it wrong and that isn't how we start the docker container. The exploded archive case really is 25% faster with Spring Boot 2.2. Really. But not relevant if no-one is actually doing that.
our docker images was exploded formerly. you can verify, and at any rate the only change is to switch the version. just I spent a lot of time trying to prove 2.2 was faster and failed.

the main thing is that PropertiesLauncher is indeed a dog. we have no need to run that in our main image. So main class vs main class performance is near identical if you start several times. at least on my host.  changing other variables have decreased startup, just not switching this one.
PropertiesLauncher is not a dog in 2.2. That was the point. But if we really aren't using it, then it doesn't matter (I thought I saw it, but maybe looking in the wrong place).
2.1 I meant, but right we only need that when doing layered images. We don't need to in the base image.

indeed we accidentally used it in our docker image on the base image, but this is reverted. IOTW, the main thing was avoiding unnecessary use of `PropertiesLauncher` not switching versions. A bump in perf for the layers which may use `PropertiesLauncher` will be welcome, but that's not what folks are watching. They are watching our base image perf.
here's the related thing btw https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin/pull/229

yeah. I dont know how to build this locally. this one definitely need your
eyes on. please adjust if anything obvious like this.

is this normal? seems like is missing jmx modules or something.
ref: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/compare/bumps-docker...jeqo:bumps-docker

Ah that's probably the error I saw earlier when removing the `java.management` module from the JRE image. I had just assumed it was a hard stop and left management in, but didn't think that it might just be an ignorable warning. Since we don't support JMX, if we can figure out a way to squash that message we'll be able to have our JRE image without the management modules.

Not sure we can do more than printing a message to ignore this error log.

After some research exception happens here:

https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/blob/d484b898218897a813eba67fc0aee62839282fce/log4j-core/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/core/LoggerContext.java#L558-L563

I can't manage to find an alternative path where this log is not printed. Found this bug description on their JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-716?focusedCommentId=14063529&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-14063529

push the tag.

Nope won't work, maven-shade requires dependencies to have runtime scope (hence gson being set to optional and not provided, and the enforcer plugin cannot target the optional dependencies because that's not even a scope. Closing this worthwhile idea :/
actually the shading of gson is something that has been problematic (it stains the classpath of tests which you'll notice in the other maven poms). It is on my list to remove anyway.
Realized we had a test explicitly verifying it defaulted to 80 or 443 - assuming it's fine to delete the test
fyi @openzipkin/cassandra cassandra test image is being re-homed

Just to confirm, is this the "run a smoke test" against the Docker image, which we started doing for `openzipkin/zipkin`? I think @saturnism is working on it for `zipkin-gcp` :) Getting the breakage notification from `zipkin-gcp` would be simple, syncing that status back to cause a failure here might be tough and I'm not sure if it's worth much.

sorry I didn't mean to test downstream. I meant the same sort of smoke test that is in zipkin-gcp, to do it here on master build. A simplified version as we don't need to integrate much.. maybe just hit health check with elasticsearch storage (or even not elasticsearch) https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-gcp/blob/master/travis/publish.sh#L107

Ah yeah we have that smoke test for the normal build too in zipkin-gcp. That isn't our docker setup though, just runs the jars. @saturnism is working on doing similar for the docker setup in zipkin-gcp.

In this repo, it's the opposite :) We don't run any smoke test on the jars, but do run it on the docker image

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/docker/docker-compose.test.yml

After getting closer to the end of the migration, was going to send an email or such notification to the members that they should go to Docker Hub settings to turn on notifications for build failures, to see the errors for that test. I think it also would mark the commit with a failure on GitHub (the red X instead of green check) but not sure since we haven't had a docker smoke test failure yet.

Is there anything else you have in mind?

As for k8s, sounds like a beast ;)

I suppose I mean invoking docker-compose.test.yml automatically. let's update this issue or close it once that happens.

k8s is maybe a beast, but that's also the world we're in. I have no idea how it starts in such a way that screws with the path of zipkin, but that's a good reason for a smoke test IMHO. that or we can just start docker with a wonky path..

Yeah Docker Hub automatically invokes docker-compose.test.yml after building the image, and if that fails, it won't push a tag and will send a failure notification. So probably already good there.

Agree it's nice to smoke test kube too - because it's a beast will take some thought on a good way though.

ic that's good.. maybe though people ignore notifications. I know I ignore perpetually failing ones. I think we should kill the build here if possible, as that makes it impossible to ignore. unless we think that there is a reason to publish a snapshot with a failing image, or that the time to create it will be too long.. 

(ps we should check both zipkin and slimbo)
It would be useful to be able to visualise percentile-based durations in some way.  E.g. p99 of spans for a particular edge in the dependency graph have a duration of 123ms or less

@jeqo I think only https://github.com/jeqo/zipkin-storage-kafka could produce the data for this, as it implies 100% collection and processing of it. Unless it is a small amount of traces which could be done client-side. That or a different system like haystack
there *may* be some on-demand, but cached aggregation features in ES at the moment.. no idea.

from @devinsba 

> Kubernetes is using this to test Kubernetes, I think we could spin a parallel build on travis to test it: https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/kind

To add color to this, the original kube breakage we wanted to fix did not repro on Google Kubernetes Engine or kind. It seemed to have to do with platform-specific way of setting up container filesystems, which reprod on docker desktop kube, and possibly others if they use a similar scheme. Interestingly it reprod with docker itself after just installing kube, which mucked with file systems.

Given all the variables, I don't know how much value testing with something like kind will add, it implements everything using docker so has very similar behavior to `docker run`, which we're already testing via the compose file.

agree k8s testing wouldn't have caught this. it was an issue on os/x after k8s installed on docker for mac, and probably wouldn't happen after reboot either. Once it mucked the system, the same problem existed in normal docker, so normal docker is good enough as we aren't supporting docker itself, just our build of zipkin.

good idea

it occurred to me maybe this is not precise? the problem is when a blank host is present. if it is http://host it should still default to port 80. I was wondering if maybe this change could possibly coerce http://host into http://host:9200 when the intent was coercing a plain hostname into http://hostname:9200

sounds fine, but please also watch this issue because tagging request/response bodies is generally problematic for reasons like this and also it can clog up the data pipeline. There are other tools like Haystack Blobs which can eventually integrate in such a way that you see links not huge data cc @ mchandramouli  https://github.com/ExpediaDotCom/haystack-blob-example/issues/5

	at java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool$WorkQueue.topLevelExec(ForkJoinPool.java:1020) [?:?]
	at java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool.scan(ForkJoinPool.java:1656) [?:?]
	at java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool.runWorker(ForkJoinPool.java:1594) [?:?]
	at java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinWorkerThread.run(ForkJoinWorkerThread.java:177) [?:?]
```

Ah that is because we use `Stream.parallel` in the health component which pushes to an untraced forkjoinpool. I was a bit nervous about that since I tend to find `parallel`'s threading model too opaque, but didn't mention it in the code review. Next time I will though :) I can help untangle that don't think it needs to be in this PR.
thanks again!
